title: Print, "American Airlines to Europe", ca. 1948
signed: Signed in grey ink, lower right: E. McKnight Kauffer
inscribed: Printed in black ink, lower right: Litho in USA
provenance: Mrs. Edward McKnight Kauffer; 1963: acquired by Museum
creditline: Gift of Mrs. E. McKnight Kauffer
description:
On a peach-colored gradient ground, a green and grey kiosk. Above in black and peach: AMERICAN AIRLINES; below, in blue: TO / EUROPE. Turret is covered with posters that read: LONDON / HOLLAND / DENMARK / SWEDEN / NORWAY / ENGLAND / ICELAND / SCOTLAND / FINLAND GERMANY / IRELAND / PARIS [AA logo].
Below, in two blocks of black text: “For the person who visits Europe, the posters / displayed on the Kiosks there give him informa- / tion about theatres, concerts, aperitifs, patent / medicines, etc. To the traveler, it is one of the / most characteristic objects that he sees upon en- / tering large European cities. These cylinders of / information therefore become a symbol of the / life of the city, and being cylinder, it is from the / point of view of design a strong and commanding / form – a column of interest. The various colors of / the posters and different typographical arrange- / ments are often so accidentally placed in juxta- / position that from a distance the effect of the / pattern is not unlike “modern” design. / “chose this therefore as a symbol because of / its commanding simplicity of form – its gaiety to / the eye and its very definite association with / Europe. There is nothing intricate in the struc- / ture of the design – nor need there be. Only on / the surface of the Kiosk is introduced color and / shape.” / E. McKNIGHT KAUFFER.

tombstone.epitaph: Print, "American Airlines to Europe", ca. 1948. Lithograph on paper. Gift of Mrs. E. McKnight Kauffer. 1963-39-164-b.
